Let $z_1,z_2,\ldots \in [0,1]$ be an infinite sequence, and define the discrepancy\[D_N(I) = \#\{ n\leq N : z_n\in I\} - N\lvert I\rvert.\]Must there exist some interval $I\subseteq [0,1]$ such that\[\limsup_{N\to \infty}\lvert D_N(I)\rvert =\infty?\]



The answer is yes, as proved by Schmidt \cite{Sc68}, who later showed \cite{Sc72} that in fact this is true for all but countably many intervals of the shape $[0,x]$.

Essentially the best possible result was proved by Tijdeman and Wagner \cite{TiWa80}, who proved that, for almost all intervals of the shape $[0,x)$, we have\[\limsup_{N\to \infty}\frac{\lvert D_N([0,x))\rvert}{\log N}\gg 1.\]




References


[Sc68] Schmidt, Wolfgang M., Irregularities of distribution. Quart. J. Math. Oxford Ser. (2) (1968), 181-191.

[Sc72] Schmidt, Wolfgang M., Irregularities of distribution. VI. Compositio Math. (1972), 63-74.

[TiWa80] Tijdeman, R. and Wagner, G., A sequence has almost nowhere small discrepancy. Monatsh. Math. (1980), 315-329.
